text.p: These are the leading stories in the Egyptian press on Saturday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- An Egyptian is arrested on suspicion of spying for Israel. A security authority revealed that Egyptian national Samir Osman, 47, has been working for years with Mossad, the Israeli secret service.
- Agriculture and Land Reclamation Minister Youssef Wali says that average productivity in cotton has set a record high.
- A "veto" war has started at the United Nations. World diplomatic confrontation on re-electing Boutros Boutros-Ghali as secretary general.

- Prime Minister Kamal Ganzouri studies the execution of projects worth $6.8 billion. Ganzouri will hold a meeting next week to discuss the projects, still under negotiation with Egyptian, Arab and foreign investors.
- The first phase of Toshka overflow will cost six billion pounds.The government has started studies on the Toshka canal, which will help in the reclamation of 500,000 feddans in the western desert.

- Industry Minister Soleiman Reda said planned investment of 458 million pounds will be cut from the cost of a three billion pound phosphate project in the western desert. An international bid to supply equipment will be announced within days, he added.
- A hoax delayed an Egyptian passenger plane at Jeddah airport for nine hours. The Cairo airport authorities received an anonymous call that a bomb was planted on the plane.
